Prerequisites: Participants must have good knowledge on planning networks composed of 1830 PSS (Photonic Service Switch) network elements and the 1830 PSS Engineering & Planning Tool (EPT) in R8.
More information: 1830 PSS Engineering & Planning Tool (EPT) R8.x to R9.1 Delta (TOP54116 - 2 days)

The differences between the NetAct standard and the cloud deliveries and the differences in the administration tasks and responsibilities will be presented. There are no exercises for the students: trainer will present practical parts as demonstration.
Objectives:
• identify the differences between the standard delivery of NetAct and the Cloud delivery.
  • identify the new administration tasks and responsibilities for the NetAct Cloud Administrator.
  • explain the new high availability functions available for NetAct cloud.
  • verify the new functions for load balancing provided in NetAct cloud.
  • explain the implementation of DCN for NetAct cloud deliveries.
  • explain the backup strategies implemented in NetAct cloud.

Title: LTE Certification Program
Description:
Gain knowledge & proficiency from a leader in LTE

The Nokia LTE Certification program accelerates time to market

To know more about our LTE certification program please download our LTE leaflet here.

Nokia LTE Certification Program consists of seven certifications, divided into two job oriented programs, one focusing on OAM job roles and the other one focusing on RF Optimization and Cells Design roles (click on related programs below for more details) :

Title: LTE Networks Operation Certification Program
Description:
The Nokia LTE Networks Operation Training & Certification Program contains two different levels of expertise from Nokia Certified Associate (NCA) level to Nokia Certified Professional (NCP) level . For every level one or more separate training & certifications are available.

Below the complete training & certification program for LTE RAN Operation Administration and Maintenance, LTE Network Operation Center and VoLTE Operation. Click on any of the levels for more details. A certification tag © indicates that a certification exam is offered for that level.

Blank Box

Nokia Certified Professional (NCP)

Title: LTE RF Optimization & Design Certification Program
Description:
The Nokia LTE RF Optimization and Design Training & Certification Program contains two different levels of expertise from Nokia Certified Associate (NCA) level to Nokia Certified Professional (NCP) level . For every level one or more separate training & certifications are available.

Below the complete training & certification program for FDD-RF Optimizer, TD-LTE RF Optimizer and LTE Radio Network Planner . Click on any of the levels for more details. A certification tag © indicates that a certification exam is offered for that level.

Blank Box

Title: NCA (Nokia Certified Associate) LTE Networks Fundamentals
Audience: LTE Networks Fundamentals
Description: The Certification Program for LTE Networks Fundamentals is designed for people who are performing the following tasks: Understanding the LTE radio technology, Understanding the LTE architecture, Creation of a high-level LTE Network configuration, Technical and commercial offer for LTE Solution, Supporting LTE product & services demonstration, Designing test plans, Standards and radio features Documentation development, Radio features definition, Customer value definition
Objectives:
By passing this exam, the candidate will have demonstrated that he is be able to:

  • List the detailed architectural elements of a mobile network and its evolution toward LTE,
  • Identify all functions and interfaces of each LTE Nodes,
  • Detail all steps of mobile call establishment,
  • Describe the packet service continuity during mobility,
  • Describe the voice services continuity during mobility,
  • Define the new LTE QoS model,
  • List how and where the security is implemented,
  • Describe the IP transport layer in the Radio Access Network,
  • List the key RF differentiators of the LTE standard compared to the other technologies,
  • Define the principles of OFDMA,
  • Describe the structure of the radio frame and how the channels (logical, transport and physical) are mapped on to the resources,
  • List the different antenna systems available and compare their interest,
  • Describe the mechanism of mobility when the UE is connected (handover) and when the UE is not connected (idle mode and paging)
Duration:
Equivalent to 10 hours training (Self-Study option) or 21 hours (Instructor Led)

Exam test: 35 questions/60 min.
Prerequisites: No mandatory Prerequisites, nevertheless background in wireless telecommunication network is recommended.
More information:

Title: What 5G is and what it isn’t| TM5141-01A-5GR_WBT
Description: 5G is on the horizon. Are you ready? Future mobile technologies usher in new paradigms for connected society. In the 2020 timeframe and beyond mobile technologies will bring together people along with things, data, applications, transport systems and cities in a smart networked communications ecosystem. This training focuses on yet-to-be-standardized 5G as it has been developed so far and the areas of technological innovation needed to deliver the 5G vision. Learn what is driving 5G, the technical performance requirements for the radio systems to support 5G, taking into account the needs of a wide portfolio of future scenarios, and use cases. Learn what 5G networks will look like, when it will be deployed and how you can prepare for 5G today.
Objectives:
History of Cellular Networks 

•recall the evolution of different generations of mobile-communication technology

•list the Key differentiators and weakness of each generation of wireless technology

Key 5G Drivers 

•explain why we will need 5G

•explain what is Driving 5G

•explain why 4G is not enough

What 5G is and what it isn’t 

•explain what 5G is and what it is not

Title: Landscape of major 5G industry activities | TM5148-01A-5GR_WBT
Description: 5G is on the horizon. Are you ready? Future mobile technologies usher in new paradigms for connected society. In the 2020 timeframe and beyond mobile technologies will bring together people along with things, data, applications, transport systems and cities in a smart networked communications ecosystem. This training focuses on yet-to-be-standardized 5G as it has been developed so far and the areas of technological innovation needed to deliver the 5G vision. Learn what is driving 5G, the technical performance requirements for the radio systems to support 5G, taking into account the needs of a wide portfolio of future scenarios, and use cases. Learn what 5G networks will look like, when it will be deployed and how you can prepare for 5G today.
Objectives:
Landscape of major 5G industry activities 

  • list major 5G industry activities
  • describe ITU R 5G related activities
  • describe NGMN 5G related activities
  • describe 3GPP work on 5G
  • explain 5G related European Union projects
  • explain 5G related activities in Asia
  • explain 5G related activities in the Americas
  • Identify Nokia key role within 5G industry cooperation
More information: Landscape of major 5G industry activities | TM5148-01A-5GR_WBT

Title: Network Operations and Maintenance Tasks with NetAct (NetAct 17.2) | OS8212-17A-NRM_CILT
Description:
This course is meant for NetAct Key users. In this course, you will learn features and hints to better use NetAct. 

In this course, all NetAct Applications are covered: 

  • Fault Management, 
  • Performance Management and 
  • Configuration Management. 
  • Note NetAct Administration such as User Management is not covered in this course. 

There are also subset of this course: Fault Management only and Performance management only.
Objectives:
• describe the purpose, architecture and functionalities of NetAct
  • use effectively NetAct Documentation
  • use NetAct Monitor tools to perform network fault analysis and network topology handling.
  • use NetAct Performance Management applications to manage Traffic Measurements, Reports, KPIs, and monitor performance indicators.
  • use the Configurator tools for executing basic tasks for configuration upload, plan management, data export and CM history reporting.
  • use NetAct for executing basic License Management tasks: license reporting, license import and distribution.set up tasks to manage the SW configuration for the network elements.
  • create network element remote backups and transfer backups to NetAct
Prerequisites: None
More information: Network Operations and Maintenance Tasks with NetAct  ( OS8212-17A 4 days)

Title: NetAct Introduction | OS0582-17A
Description:
NetAct Introductory course targeted to all who use and administrate NetAct.

This course is designed to introduce to NetAct System and its capabilities. The training is composed by 6 Web Based Training, each focusing on a separate topic: NetAct Overview, Fault Management, Configuration Management, Performance Management, User Management and NetAct System Monitoring. The course starts with an overview of the system, explaining its purpose and architecture. The student is walked through the applications composing NetAct system, and will learn about their functions and usage. The following chapters focus on a specific topic, each describing the functionalities available in NetAct to address areas of Fault Management, Performance Management, Configuration Management, User Management and System Monitoring. NetAct tools and features are explored.
Objectives:
• recognize the purpose of NetAct and its related applications
  • describe the architecture of the NetAct System
  • describe how NetAct applications are used for basic monitoring, configuration and management of the network.
Prerequisites: None
More information: Introduction to NetAct  (OS0582-17 - 2 hours)

Title: TAS (Telecom Application Server) Application Deployment
Url: TAS (Telecom Application Server) Application Deployment| CN64220-K-1705
Description:
This set of 13 videos describes how to deploy the Nokia TAS on a Cloud platform. The curriculum is composed of brief videos organized in four sections.

1. The first section is an introduction to the course and provides information such as learning objectives.

2. The second section contains information on the environment used in this deployment demonstration.

3. The third section shows the step-by-step procedures for Nokia TAS deployment.

4. The last section is a video that summarizes the deployment procedure in macro-tasks and concludes the course.

NOTE: This curriculum assumes that Airframe hardware with CBIS (CloudBand Infrastructure Software) and CBAM (CloudBand Application Manager) are already installed and configured.
Objectives: Demonstrate the steps needed to deploy the Nokia TAS VNF (Virtual Network Function)  application on top of a cloud platform prepared for VNF deployment.
Prerequisites:
• Good knowledge of Telco Cloud Technology

• Good knowledge of CloudBand
More information:
TAS (Telecom Application Server) Application Deployment(1 hr. 50 mins.)

Title: TCP/IP based LTE Radio performance analysis and troubleshooting | RA4708-01A-LTE_CILT
Audience: TCP/IP based LTE Radio performance analysis and troubleshooting
Description:
• TCP/IP and LTE Air Interface basics
  • Tools
  • Result Interpretation
  • Use case 
Target Audience
  • Personnel who plan FDD-LTE radio or access networks
  • Personnel who optimize FDD-LTE radio or access networks
  • Personnel who manage the performance of FDD-LTE radio or access networks 

Note:

 This course does not deal with IPv6 specifics
Objectives:
The participant is able to:

  • explain the end-to-end TCP/IP architecture
  • list and explain factors which could degrade TCP throughput
  • analyze Wireshark traces in terms of network troubleshooting and optimization
  • isolate links causing delay and/or packet loss
  • examine why throughput is low in good radio conditions

In detail the participant is able to:

TCP/IP and LTE Air Interface basics
  • recall the basics of TCP/IP
  • explain how TCP behaves over the radio interface
  • examine how the radio interface procedures like HARQ/RLC retransmission and Scheduling affect the throughput
  • apply TCP throughput models

Tools

  • identify Packet Loss and Radio Retransmission events using advanced tools – Wireshark & R
  • determine where throughput issues originate from with Single Wireshark Trace Analysis
  • determine where throughput issues originate from with Mutliple Wireshark Trace Analysis
  • determine where throughput issues originate from with Single Wireshark Trace Analysis with Nemo
Result Interpretation
  • interpret trace results to pinpoint network issues

Use case

  • evaluate a practical example as presented by the trainer
Prerequisites:
• Working experience with LTE Radio Planning or Optimisation
  • Good knowledge about IP and LTE technology
  • Good knowledge about Nokia LTE equipment
  • RA4121

Title: CDP Installation & Administration
Description:
The Installation and Administration curriculum, provides the platform administrators the knowledge to manage licenses, understanding logs, database operations, user and tenant management.

As well as an introduction to the Device libraries.

IDuring 4Q2017 the Installation training will be added to this curriculum
Objectives:
• Manage roles for permissions
  • Manage tenants and users in CDP
  • Manage CDP application license
  • Add and manage new device type
  • Manage device firmware images including UPC file
  • Edit and restore scripted primitives in CDP
  • Manage logs in CDP
  • Manage CDP servers
  • Perform platform health check

  • Explain the different components of Device Library Updates (DLU) in CDP

  • Download and upload a device library to CDP

  • Manage brands and devices in DLU

  • Manage primitives in DLU to support device capability function

  • Manage enumerations in DLU to support mapping between DLU components
Prerequisites: We recommend you to first complete the CDP Fundamentals & Positioning learning solution

Title: CDP Device Provisioning, Operations & NBI
Description:
This curriculum provides the hands-on experience on how to perform device management, run actions and policies on devices, and perform device firmware upgrades via the CDP platform.

As well as an introduction to the Entitlement server and the Rich Communication Suite.

In a later phase, more management applications will be explained, such as ONTs and IoT.

And the important aspects of the CDP troubleshooting.

All learning is default offered as self-paced learning.
Objectives:
• Navigate the CDP dashboard
  • Onboard devices in CDP
  • Perform basic device management operations
  • Execute actions on devices
  • Create policies to execute jobs on devices
  • Perform policy chaining for multiple jobs
  • Create and schedule campaigns for devices

  • Explain the purpose of CDP-ES,

  • List and explain the Use-cases for CDP-ES

  • Explain CDP integration with Nokia OneNDS, with Nokia SMP, and with Carrier IT System

  • Explain JMX counters and SNMP alarms in CDP

  • Explain CDP as an RCS Configuration Server

  • Explain the configurations required in CDP to manage RCS Clients

  • Describe the CDP functional architecture
Prerequisites: We recommend you to first complete the CDP Fundamentals & Positioning learning solution

Title: CDP Fundamentals and positioning
Description: This curriculum will give you a good basic understanding of the Connected Device Platform, including an short introduction video

Description: Our Motive® Connected Device Platform (CDP) helps you reduce OPEX and TCO for device management and deliver better customer experiences for mobile, home and Internet of Things (IoT) services. The Motive CDP is a multi-tenant, converged cloud platform that securely manages all types of connected devices.

Title: Rapport (Cloud PBX) 17.07 Operations and Maintenance Curriculum
Description: This self-paced curriculum consists of two Cloud PBX 17.07 e-learning curricula.  Cloud PBX, formerly known as Rapport Enterprise Communication is a Cloud PBX replacement solution targeted toward XLE (Extra Large Enterprise) customers.  The curriculum consists of two curricula: Nokia Rapport (Cloud PBX) Overview and Nokia Rapport (Cloud PBX) Maintenance and Service Provisioning.

Title: Rapport (Cloud PBX) Overview| AP00118-K-1707
Description:
The Nokia Rapport Enterprise Communication platform (also known as Cloud PBX) is an open, horizontally integrated framework for delivering communications solutions. This Cloud PBX replacement solution is a solution constructed within the framework, as is the Nokia Rapport Applications Integration solution.

This course provides an overview of the Nokia Rapport (Cloud PBX) platform, and is presented in a series of short, recorded WBT sessions. Participants will learn about the Nokia Cloud PBX framework, the Nokia Cloud PBX core micro services, and be given an overview of OAM and P.

CONTENT

• Section 1 – Nokia Rapport Overview

• Section 2 – Nokia Rapport Architecture

• Section 3 – Enterprise Communication Service

• Section 4 – Enterprise Application Server

• Section 5 – OAM and P

Course Layout:

You will begin by taking the pretest (optional) to gauge your current knowledge level of Rapport. You will then read the CourseIntroduction.pdf which describes the course. Next you will watch 18 short videos within sections 1 – 5. You will then read the CourseSummary.pdf section. Last you will take the Final Exam (optional).

To have this course marked as complete on your Nokia Learning and Development Hub transcript you must read the 2 pdf files and watch the 18 videos. If you do not need to have your transcript marked complete you have the option of only reading or watching the learning objects that are of interest to you. Nokia does not require that you pass the final exam, but your company may require it. Check your local procedures.
Objectives:
By the end of the course, participants will be able to:

• Describe the functions, features, and architecture of the Nokia Rapport platform,

• Describe the functions and features of the Nokia Rapport micro services,

• Describe the FCAPS management of the Nokia Rapport platform.

CONTENT

3. Watch short videos within sections 1 – 6.

4. Read the CourseSummary.pdf section.

5. Last you will take the Final Exam (optional).

If you do not need to have your transcript marked complete you have the option of only reading or watching the learning objects that are of interest to you. Nokia does not require that you pass the final exam, but your company may require it. Check your local procedures.
Objectives:

Title: NCP (Nokia Certified Professional) Radio Network Optimization FDD-LTE
Audience: designed for individual who need to specialized into FDD LTE RF Optimization.
Description: The Certification Program for Radio Network Optimization FDD-LTE is designed for people who are performing the following tasks: Configuring LTE FDD Radio Networks Performance. Monitoring and detecting LTE FDD Radio Networks issues due to bad QoS.
Objectives:
By passing this exam, the candidate will have demonstrated that he is be able to:

  • List the main steps of the LTE FDD RAN optimization process and associated Nokia tools,
  • Classify the Nokia e-Node B FDD parameters,
  • Describe the main FDD Radio Resources Management mechanisms and their associated parameters (MIMO, resources allocation, Physical Channel Configuration, link adaptation),
  • Describe the Call Setup procedures and their associated parameters (RRC Connection, Idle mode, S1 and X2 bearer setup, ...),
  • Describe the Mobility Management procedures and their associated parameters (Standby mode, Active mode),
  • List the main Nokia Performance Monitoring tools,
  • List the main counters and indicators to monitor the key LTE FDD RAN Performance issues (accessibility, retain ability, mobility, traffic load, radio condition),
  • Detect typical LTE FDD RAN performance issues through use cases analysis.

Learning track [112 hours/16 days]

Written exam 45 Questions/2 Hours
Prerequisites: Passed the NCA (Nokia Certified Associate) LTE Networks Fundamentals

Title: NCP (Nokia Certified Professional) CORE (VoLTE) Operation and Maintenance
Audience: designed for individual who need to specialized into VoLTE Core network operation
Description: The Certification Program for CORE (VoLTE) Operation And Maintenance is designed for people who are performing the following tasks: VoLTE Core Network monitoring, performance management, configuration management, software and license management for TAS and NTHLR from the central EMS.
Objectives:
By passing this exam, the candidate will have demonstrated that he is be able to:

  • Describe VoLTE Architecture and Subscriber Registration
  • Describe VoLTE Call Setup Procedure
  • Describe VoLTE Roaming and CS Interworking
  • Describe how NetAct applications are used for basic monitoring, configuration and management of the network
  • Utilize NetAct Monitor tools to perform network fault analysis and network topology handling.
  • Utilize NetAct Performance Management applications to manage Traffic Measurements, Reports, KPIs, and monitor performance indicators.
  • Utilize the Configurator tools for executing basic tasks for configuration upload, plan management, data export and CM history reporting.
  • Utilize NetAct for executing basic License Management tasks: license reporting, license import and distribution.
  • Set up tasks to manage the SW configuration for the network elements.
  • Create network element remote backups
Duration:
Learning track [63 hours/9 days]

Written exam 45 Questions/2 Hours
Prerequisites: Passed the NCA (Nokia Certified Associate) LTE Networks Fundamentals
More information:
Program Package | CN00180-K-0001 --> (Recommended Learning)

NCP - CORE (VOLTE) Operation And Maintenance | CN00180-F-0001(Online exam 2 hours)

Blended Learning Track(WBT and Classroom courses)

VoLTE Call Setup Procedure Overview | CN61010-W-175(WBT 13 min - Nov. 2017)

VoLTE Roaming and CS Interworking Overview | CN61020-W-175(WBT 33min - Nov. 2017)

VoLTE e2e Signaling| CN6112-16A-COR_CILT(CILT 35 h)

NetAct for VoLTE (NetAct 16.x)| OS8213-16A-NRM_CILT(CILT 28 h)

Online course (Additional Self-Study Material)

Introduction to NetAct 17 | OS0582-17A-NRM(WBT 2 hours)

Title: One-EIR 17 to 18 Delta | CN00062-K-1711
Description: This curriculum provides for experience administrators and operators a look at features being introduced in 17.5 and 18 release for One-EIR
Objectives:
The trainee is able to

  •  describe how release 18 supports SVs in IMEI ranges
  •  describe deployment of the cloud environment under CBAM control
  •  describe provisioning GUI for One-EIR
  •  describe platform and security improvements
Prerequisites: Experience with 16.5 release

Title: One-MNP 17 to 18 Delta | CN00063-K-18
Description: This curriculum covers the key feature changes and impact from One-MNP 17 to One-MNP 18 releases.
Objectives:
In detail the participant is able to:

Fixed Number Portability

  •  identify the differences between earlier and new implementation of the feature
  •  recognize the impact on the Directory Information Tree
  •  recall basic requirements to configure the feature using the reference documents

Basic ENUM functionality in One-MNP

  •  recall the ENUM concept
  •  name the usage modes of the feature
  •  define basic requirements to configure the feature using the reference documents

Optimal routing support in One-MNP

  •  identify the concept and benefits of the network traffic feature
  •  recognize the MAP protocol implementation of the feature
  •  recall basic requirements to configure the feature using the reference documents

One-MNP Open Stack deployment via CBAM

  •  recall the basic concept and flow of One-MNP 18 Open Stack/VMware deployment via CBAM
  •  recall basic requirements for the feature using the reference documents

Provisioning GUI for One-EIR and One-MNP

  •  explain the limitations of the previous One-MNP provisioning concept
  •  recall the concept of the new provisioning tool
  •  describe the benefits of the new provisioning tool

Platform and security improvements

  • list the enhancements introduced between Rel. 17-18
  • describe the recognized enhancements
Prerequisites: Experience with One-MNP/One-NDS previous implementations

Title: Future X Workshops
Description:
We are at the dawn of a new era of human existence that will be shaped by digitization with the goal of automating much of life and augmenting our intelligence - effectively creating time.

The Future X Workshop Series explores Bell Labs’ view of this future, examining the key technological breakthroughs that will be essential at both the architectural and systems levels. It provides the basis for discussion about future business models and critical business issues. This series includes an introductory workshop that addresses the over-arching concepts of leading Future X domains, as well as several deeper dive domain workshops.

Key questions addressed across the workshop series include:

  • What are the fundamentals of the Bell Labs Future X vision, its 8 value vectors and its relevance for network transformation?
  • What are the coming technological, network architecture and operations changes, and how to incorporate this knowledge as part of a strategic business plan?
  • What is the impact of cloudification and its effect on market dynamics?
  • What steps are mandatory in preparing for 5G?
  • What new digital services are emerging and what requirements will they impose on my network?
  • How can I effectively incorporate data analytics and machine learning as part of a comprehensive Future X evolution?
  • What opportunities and threats are triggered by the evolution of new business and operating paradigms?

These workshops are designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining best practices that you can start to implement today.

Title: Future X Workshop: Leveraging Data Analytics
Audience: For thought leaders in the telecommunication industry
Description:
At the cusp of the current information revolution, big data analytics platforms and machine learning (ML) techniques are playing a central role. They are becoming an increasingly critical differentiating factor in accelerating digital transformation and the emergence of new business models.

In the Future X network, hyper-scale analytics and intelligent automation play a central role. Using real-time analytics, network programmability and automated control, it is possible to enable an intelligent network operating system that communicate effectively with distributed intelligent modules.

This workshop is customized for the application of ML and big data analytics by telecom service providers, focusing on topics relevant to Future X networks. It discusses practical insights, industry benchmarks, near-term applications and future trends relevant to the telecommunications industry.

Course Outine

Day 1

The Future X Network Vision

  • Review the digital pyramid of human needs. Explain the value of time: of saving and generating time.
  • Explore the 100 years, 100x shift in network architecture.
  • Explore the evolution of productivity gains as a result of technology evolutions. Discuss the emerging need to connect everything.
  • Introduce the five megatrends in the industry and discuss their implication for services and traffic.
  • Explain the Future X network: cognitive, converged and cloud-optimized.

Industry Trends and Opportunities

  • Define the meaning and scope of key data analytics concepts: machine learning (ML), big data, augmented intelligence, and prediction.
  • Survey the telco spectrum of applications using data analytics: fault detection, service introduction, and customer experience monetization.
  • Investigate the underlying enablers of telco opportunities: cloud-based data, new advances in software, and intelligent algorithms.

Data Analytics as a Key Element of Future X Networks

  • Understand where and how data analytics will be deployed in Future X networks.
  • Describe how performance measurements are applicable to different types of data analytics techniques, and the industry benchmarks for each type of measurement.
  • Explain how data analytics evolves toward artificial intelligence.

Considerations for Successful Data Analytics: Concepts and Use Cases

  • Articulate industry best practices on how to use data analytics to drive business outcomes. Topics include: customer experience, capital efficiency, and service agility improvements.
  • Provide examples of sound governance methods based on best practices. Examples include: compliance, security, and privacy.
  • Explore future thought, through an augmented intelligence exercise. 

Day 2

Real-world Solutions for Service Providers

  • Examine network analysis solutions: 1) Selectively upgrading macro sites to reduce CAPEX; 2) Detecting and monitoring IoT performance; 3) Sustaining network equipment via life-cycle analytics.
  • Examine customer experience solutions: 1) Classifying (re-classifying) customer care tickets via sentiment analysis; 2) Reducing truck-rolls via dynamic intelligent workflow; 3) Predicting subscriber churn via social network analytics.

Getting Started: Monetizing the Hidden Value of Data

  • Survey results focus: Selling to your customer's preferences by analyzing feedback previously obtained through focus groups and social media.
  • Pricing focus: Maximizing revenue by modeling the elasticity of your service offerings.
  • Targeted data focus: Exploiting your anonymized location, usage, and subscriber data as strategic assets useful for other sectors such as retail, media, and tourism.

Positioning for Future X via Data Analytics

  • Articulate the value of establishing a corporate culture of big data.
  • Describe currently available state-of-the-art solutions using commercial and open-source tools for analysis, data visualization, and self-generating reports.
  • Explain how to implement a dedicated data repository (data lake) for analytics.
  • Show how applying a series of simple algorithms to your proprietary data over time can build toward a winning strategy for the future.
Objectives:
After completion of this workshop you should be able to:

  • Identify telco opportunities for leveraging big data analytics; including new business models and high-value solutions for the digital economy
  • Understand where and how machine learning will be deployed in Future X networks
  • List examples of data collection and governance methods based on best practices
  • Articulate industry best practices on how to use data analytics to drive business outcomes, including customer experience, capital efficiency and service agility improvements
  • Describe best practices for performance measurement applicable to different types of ML techniques, and industry benchmarks for each type of measurement
  • Explain how ML evolves toward artificial intelligence

This workshop is designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining best practices that you can start to implement today.
Duration: A two day highly interactive workshop delivered at a Bell Labs location in Europe, the Americas or Asia Pacific, or at a customer location upon request

Title: Future X Workshop: Realizing the Benefits of Cloud SDN/NFV
Audience: For thought leaders in the telecommunication industry
Description:
Cloud SDN/NFV technologies are a core element of the Future X network. These technologies have reached sufficient maturity for network operators to develop clearly articulated virtualization strategies and associated transformation plans in a bid to remain competitive. While SDN and NFV offer significant potential for expanding services, cutting costs and improving agility, they also present difficult implementation challenges.

This workshop addresses the technology, architecture and strategy pillars of SDN/NFV, and provides a global perspective of emerging trends, industry best practices and key near-term steps. It is intended to help service providers create an actionable transformation strategy to adopt SDN/NFV.

Course Outline

Day 1

The Future X Network Vision

  • Review the digital pyramid of human needs. Explain the value of time: of saving and generating time.
  • Explore the 100 years, 100x shift in network architecture.
  • Explore the evolution of productivity gains as a result of technology evolutions. Discuss the emerging need to connect everything.
  • Introduce the five megatrends in the industry and discuss their implication for services and traffic.
  • Explain the Future X network: cognitive, converged and cloud-optimized.

Introduction

  • Understand the basic concepts and foundational elements of cloud, virtualization, SDN, and NFV.
  • Present the business and economics value drivers for SDN/NFV technology adoption.
  • Highlight the state of SDN/NFV adoption based on a representative set of CSP initiatives.

Technology and Architecture

  • Present key virtualization technologies and their architectural progression – virtual machines, containers, microservices, and serverless computing.
  • Introduce reference SDN/NFV end-to-end architectural frameworks.
  • Introduce network and service orchestration concepts.
  • Understand the impact of an edge cloud architecture for low latency and high performance.
  • Analyze how to optimize and transform your DCs – re-architecting central offices as data centers.
  • Introduce the SDN/NFV ecosystem with focus on opensource initiatives and public cloud platforms.

 

Day 2

New Business Opportunities and Business Models

  • Understand digital disruption.
  • Explore the four technology dimensions that drive competitive differentiation.
  • Review current and likely operator use case examples.
  • Explore new business and pricing models: (1) Creation of new and enhanced dynamic services - Ansoff matrix analysis, (2) Thinking beyond connectivity (IoT services) – network slicing, smart home, and drones, (3) Market and Operator revenue assessment of SDN/NFV enabled services – focus on Enterprise aaS

Future Operations

  • Understand the impact of SDN/NFV on operations processes and platforms; examine discuss the associated operational maturity requirements.
  • Explore the required organizational transformation.
  • Discuss the role of automation, predictive analytics, and machine learning in the future evolution of operations.

Impact on Operator’s Top-line & Bottom-line

  • Explore revenue potential projections for a representative set of new services based on recent Operator activity.
  • Understand how SDN/NFV reduces network costs; explore the cost saving projections for major network elements and their operation.
  • Analyze additional cost efficiency opportunities resulting from optimization of network function distribution and node consolidation.

Security in an SDN/NFV Environment

  • Discuss new security threats introduced by cloud, virtualization, SDN, and NFV, at the network and device levels.
  • Understand how threat and vulnerability is managed in an SDN/NFV environment.
  • Understand how micro-segmentation augments DC security.
  • Explore how analytics are used to mitigate threats.
  • Evaluate the return on investment in security measures.

Transforming to an SDN/NFV Enabled Network

  • Present key operator positioning strategies in the virtual cloud-based world: global service provider vs. local access carrier.
  • Examine the maturity level of different SDN/NFV technology building blocks.
  • Understand the major adoption triggers for SDN/NFV.
  • Characterize SDN/NFV adoption risks and explore means for their evaluation and mitigation.
  • Analyze operator adoption strategies, no-regret moves, and implementation best practices, using recent reference examples.
Objectives:
After completion of this workshop you will be able to:

  • Gain insights into SDN/NFV reference architectures, adoption strategies and best practices employed by operators worldwide as they move toward a Future X network
  • Understand how Edge Cloud improves the performance of ultra-reliable, low-latency applications (URLLC)
  • Discover how SDN/NFV generates top-line growth, including dynamic enablement of 5G services and IoT applications, and the monetization of global-local cloud solutions
  • Gain insights into how SDN/NFV will impact operations, including the necessary process and platform changes, and the required organizational transformation
  • Understand how SDN/NFV can leverage predictive analytics and machine learning to enhance service revenue, reduce network costs and increase agility
  • Discover how SDN/NFV impacts overall security at the service, network and device levels – what new threats are introduced by these technologies; how do they mitigate current threats; what is the return on investment for security measures

This workshop is designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining best practices that you can start to implement today.
Duration: A two day highly interactive workshop delivered at a Bell Labs location in Europe, the Americas or Asia Pacific, or at a customer location upon request

Title: Future X Workshop: Transforming to Digital Operations
Audience: For thought leaders in the telecommunication industry
Description:
Realizing the full benefits of the Future X network, requires service providers to transform their operations from reactive support to cognitive enablement. Operations must evolve to become more service-oriented and contextualized, leading to new opportunities for monetization. This will require targeted and sustained change across the “4P” dimensions of operations (process, people, platforms and performance). Data analytics and machine-learning will be required to achieve high levels of automation across fulfilment and assurance, service personalization, and real-time restoration and optimization.

This workshop addresses the impact of digitization on network and service operations, and provides a global perspective of emerging trends and industry practices. It is intended to help organizations create an actionable transformation strategy to evolve to Future X operations.

Course Outline

Day 1

The Future X network vision

  • Review the digital pyramid of human needs. Explain the value of time: of saving and generating time.
  • Explore the 100 years, 100x shift in network architecture.
  • Explore the evolution of productivity gains as a result of technology evolutions. Discuss the emerging need to connect everything.
  • Introduce the five megatrends in the industry and discuss their implication for services and traffic.
  • Explain the Future X network: cognitive, converged and cloud-optimized.

Evolution of Network and Service Operations

  • Examine how the drivers for operations are changing from cost optimization to value generation.
  • Study the major technology triggers for digital operations such as: IoT, big data analytics, and cloud. Understand how they drive automation and personalization, and enable real-time, predictive operations.
  • Analyze the factors accelerating network-IT operations convergence, and explore the merging of standards and best practices.
  • Review web-scale providers’ successful transformation of customer and service operations and understand how these practices can be adopted by operators.

Future vision and trends

  • Examine how the Future X concepts of hyper-analytics and DevOps can help operators transform to digital operations.
  • Examine the essential components of the above evolution across the 4P dimensions: People (organization and roles), Process (across stakeholders, services and resources), Platform (systems and tools), Performance (metrics and outcomes)
  • Identify the changes to future operations organizations in areas such as team structure, roles, and staff skills.
  • Examine the evolution of processes to enable capabilities such as, zero-touch orchestration, proactive service management, and policy-triggered performance/capacity management.
  • Understand the platform architecture changes needed to support the above evolution of capabilities.
  • Discuss the shifting paradigm of performance metrics - evolving from ‘measuring and managing’ to ‘mining and monetizing’ - thanks to big data analytics.

Day 2

Establishing the maturity model as a foundation for transformation

  • Using examples, illustrate the different levels of operations maturity: reactive, proactive, predictive, and cognitive – with specific focus on digitalization and virtualization.
  • Understand the future evolution path from a maturity perspective, and how analytics and automation will be key enablers in the maturity journey.
  • Examine the best practices (across the 4P dimensions) that enable operations transformation across the maturity spectrum.

Transformation approach and examples

  • Understand how the Bell Labs xCROM (Capability Reference Operating Model) combines and customizes industry standards (e.g., eTOM and ITIL) with practical experience to provide a best practice transformation framework.
  • Analyze the pros and cons of various transformation approaches including: green-patch, brownfield, big-bang - and discuss their relevance to your business and market environment.
  • Study the transformation journeys of leading operators focusing on early lessons learned, risks encountered, and mitigation measures adopted.
Objectives:
After completion of this workshop you should be able to:

  • Identify the triggers and enablers of the Future X digital operations paradigm
  • Articulate an operations maturity model and how it can be used to drive transformation
  • Identify the impact of transformation to the Future X network across the 4P dimensions of operations
  • Understand how trends in data analytics and machine learning can be leveraged for increased automation and contextualization
  • Articulate key steps of an operations transformation program, identify major roadblocks and determine possible resolution approaches

This workshop is designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining best practices that you can start to implement today.
Duration: A two day highly interactive workshop delivered at a Bell Labs location in Europe, the Americas or Asia Pacific, or at a customer location upon request

Title: Future X Workshop: Wireless Evolution to 5G
Audience: For thought leaders in the telecommunication industry
Description:
The coming of 5G is nothing less than a revolution. Producing an explosion of possibilities, it will link people and things like never before, bridging our physical, virtual and social worlds.

Among the myriad business opportunities that can be unearthed through 5G, there are initial questions any operator faces. “What does 5G mean in my specific context?”, “What services can I offer using 5G that I cannot offer today or in the near future?”, “How can I make any money and build a business out of it?”

5G must be realized through evolution and disruptive innovations in the underlying network and associated operations.

This workshop addresses the technology, architecture and economic pillars of 5G evolution. It provides a global perspective based on industry best practices and key near-term steps. It is intended to help operators create an actionable 5G-transformation strategy.

Course Outline

Day 1

The Future X Network Vision

  • Review the digital pyramid of human needs. Explain the value of time: of saving and generating time.
  • Explore the 100 years, 100x shift in network architecture.
  • Explore the evolution of productivity gains as a result of technology evolutions. Discuss the emerging need to connect everything.
  • Introduce the five megatrends in the industry and discuss their implication for services and traffic .
  • Explain the Future X network: cognitive, converged and cloud-optimized.

5G Basics

  • Articulate the basics of 5G including drivers, requirements, capabilities, and standards status.
  • Introduce the nature of use cases and applications that are enabled by 5G including potential market opportunity.
  • Share global and regional trends for 5G introduction including Service Providers strategies, spectrum planning, ecosystem readiness, and deployment roadmap.

5G Use Case Analysis

  • Introduce and apply the Bell Labs framework for 5G use case analysis and prioritization considering technical feasibility and business potential.
  • Identify and prioritize use cases relevant for Service Providers business and technological context.
  • Examine the network requirements for a representative set of leading 5G use cases.

Target 5G Network Architecture

  • Examine the high-level impact of 5G use cases on Service Providers network and operations, including limitations of current assets.
  • Study end-to-end network dimensioning needed to realize the representative set of 5G use cases for RAN, transport, and mobile core.
  • Analyze the technology enablers required to satisfy the technical requirements of 5G use cases.
  • Identify the target 5G network architecture needed to realize the 5G use cases leveraging the required technology enablers.

 

Day 2

Transformation Roadmap

  • Explore the network and operations transformation approaches being adopted with 5G as the goal.
  • Understand the drivers and criteria for virtualization, distribution and centralization of network functions in the RAN and mobile core.
  • Analyze the strategy for 5G spectrum acquisition, site build-out for radio access, edge and centralized data centers, and deep-fiber penetration for backhaul and fronthaul networks.
  • Examine 5G deployment options considering evolution of LTE RAN and EPC; analyze non-standalone vs. standalone deployment options.
  • Identify the value proposition of the 5G next-generation core and network slicing.

Business Models and Value Creation

  • Analyze new services and the market opportunity enabled by 5G, with focus on the Service Providers value creation and role in the value chain.
  • Explore the opportunities, challenges, and competitive threats Service Providers are likely to encounter in the process. Analyze how operators can leverage their strengths, overcome weaknesses, and consider partnerships to maximize their value capture.
  • Examine cost efficiencies of 5G technology in offering mobile broadband services as compared to legacy technologies and their evolutions.

Go-to-Market Plan

  • Introduce and apply the Bell Labs business model framework to identify go-to-market strategies.
  • Examine key partnerships and business models to realize selected 5G service offers.
  • Identify key next steps for transformation of network and operations.
Objectives:
After completion of this workshop you should be able to:

  • Articulate the basics of 5G, including drivers, requirements, capabilities and standards status
  • Identify and prioritize 5G service offers relevant for your business and technological context; understand the potential business models and revenue streams
  • Examine the high-level impact of 5G service offers on your network and operations, including limitations of current assets
  • List the technology enablers needed to satisfy the technical requirements of specific 5G services
  • Recognize the steps to take today in preparation for 5G, considering implications on technology, operations and business lines: technology and spectrum migration strategies, starting with 4.5 and 4.9G, RAN cloudification at the edge for reduced latency, the move to unlicensed and higher spectrum, both sub 6GHz and mmWave, the use of massive MIMO across a denser radio network grid and, E2E network transport requirements

This workshop is designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining best practices that you can start to implement today.
Duration: A two day highly interactive workshop delivered at a Bell Labs location in Europe, the Americas or Asia Pacific, or at a customer location upon request

Title: Future X Workshop: Exploring Internet of Things
Audience: For thought leaders in the telecommunication industry
Description:
As an important driver of the Future X network, the internet of things (IoT) will entail the interconnection of tens of billions of devices to the internet, transforming how humans interact with the digital world.

Such greater data processing volumes will require innovations in network and cloud connectivity, software platforms and analytical techniques. New applications, ecosystems and business models will evolve, bringing forth dramatic disruptions such as Industry 4.0, smart city applications and automated driving.

This workshop addresses the network, platform and operations impacts of IoT, and provides a global perspective on emerging trends, industry best practices and key near-term steps. It is intended to help create an actionable digital transformation strategy to unlock the many business opportunities enabled by IoT.

Course Outline 

Day 1 

The Future X network vision

  • Review the digital pyramid of human needs. Explain the value of time: of saving and generating time.
  • Explore the 100 years, 100x shift in network architecture.
  • Explore the evolution of productivity gains as a result of technology evolutions. Discuss the emerging need to connect everything.
  • Introduce the five megatrends in the industry and discuss their implication for services and traffic.
  • Explain the Future X network: cognitive, converged and cloud-optimized.

IoT Basics

  • Articulate the basic concepts around IoT and their impact: digitization, connectivity, device evolution, data analytics, machine learning, virtualization, and microservices.
  • Understand the various stakeholders and role players and how they combine to form a mutually beneficial ecosystem for the adoption and advancement of IoT.
  • Introduce a representative set of use cases and applications that are enabled by IoT within and across industries such as financial, transportation, healthcare, and retail.

Business and Market Drivers

  • Explore the key business and customer drivers behind IoT and what aspects of IoT are likely find early market traction.
  • Understand how varying market dynamics are likely to result in different evolution and adoption paths for IoT in different regions of the world.
  • Analyze addressable markets for the various use cases and explore how IoT devices are forecast to evolve in unleashing these market opportunities.

Business Models and Value Creation

  • Using examples, introduce the concepts of value flow and value creation in IoT business models.
  • Explore how the operator creates value in the value chain, using its network and platform capabilities that comprise the ‘nerve system’ of IoT solutions.
  • Explore the process of ‘value capture’ and the opportunities, challenges/risks and competitive threats Operators are likely to encounter in the process. Analyse how operators can leverage their strengths and overcome weaknesses and examine the role partnerships can play in this process.

 

Day 2

Technology and Architecture

  • With the help of use cases, study how IoT solutions are realized with end-to-end architectures.
  • Compare various available wide area wireless connectivity solutions to understand where each option presents a ‘zone of advantage’.
  • Study IoT’s impact on access (fixed and wireless) and core networks as they evolve to provide on-demand capacity and application-specific latency, with linkages to enabling concepts such as microservices, virtualization, and dynamic orchestration.
  • Examine the role of edge cloud in meeting the agility and real-time requirements of IoT.
  • Analyse how data analytics and machine learning along with automation play a key role in the various IoT use cases.
  • At an overview level, understand the platforms that comprise the architecture and role of each platform (group) in the realization of IoT’s architectural goals.

Transforming to IoT

  • Explore the network and operations transformation approaches being adopted with IoT as the goal.
  • Study the various network transformation scenarios and the role of technologies such as 5G and small cells.
  • Describe the future vision of cognitive, service-oriented operations to support IoT.
  • Examine the customer experience evolution to manage and leverage the digital value fabric of IoT.
  • Understand how concepts such as DevOps (that enable agility in IT realization and readiness) can be customized and adapted to a hyper-dynamic, multi-vendor environment of IoT.
  • Identify the initial steps Operators will need to take as part of transformation based on a ‘readiness for IoT’ assessment.
Objectives:
After completion of this workshop you should be able to:

  • Understand IoT concepts, business drivers and challenges
  • Explore IoT applications across various industries using relevant use cases and addressable market.
  • Gain insights into the IoT value chain, stakeholders, and Operators role in the value chain, using practical examples and current operator strategies.
  • Understand the technology elements of IoT, including end-to-end architectures and platforms, and the impact on core and access networks.
  • Examine how Operators can maximize value capture via innovative business models

This workshop is designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining strategies and best practices that you can start to implement today.
Duration: A two day highly interactive workshop delivered at a Bell Labs location in Europe, the Americas or Asia Pacific, or at a customer location upon request

Title: NT HLR 17 to 18 Features Delta | CN06783-K-18
Description: This curriculum provides for experience administrators and operators a look at features being introduced in the 18 release for NT HLR system. Prerequisites: Experience with NT HLR 17 operations maintenance, and administration.
Objectives:
• describe the distributed Nokia HSS Architecture
  • recognize the deployment options for bare metal and telco cloud solution in NT HLR 18
  • list the new feature being introduced in NT HLR 18
  • describe information and requirements for the Compact VNF solution
  • describe basic information and requirements for the High Capacity VNF solution
  • describe SS7 Point Code Concentration for Bare Metal and Cloud
  • describe the improvements for NT HLR 18
Prerequisites: Experience with NT HLR 17 release

Title: 1830 PSI-2T Field Maintenance Engineer
Description: This course provides the necessary knowledge about main functionalities, architecture, hardware, provisioning and maintenance of 1830 PSI (Photonic Service Interconnect) -2T network element.
More information: 1830 PSI- 2T Overview, Operation & Maintenance (OP00002-K - 2,5 hours)

  • NT HLR OAM Specialist on Telco Cloud 18

Title: Future X Workshop: Preparing for the Coming Revolution
Audience: For thought leaders in the telecommunication industry
Description:
We are at the dawn of a new era of human existence that will be shaped by digitization with the goal of automating much of life and augmenting our intelligence effectively creating time.

Operators are being challenged to look beyond their traditional strengths, in order to successfully transform and become key players in this new digital era. This will require leveraging and monetizing innovative technologies such as cloud, internet of things, data analytics, 5G and digital operations.

This Future X introductory workshop examines the current and forthcoming breakthroughs in these technologies at both the architectural and systems levels and provides the basis for discussion of the critical business issues that need to be considered today.

It discusses practical insights, industry trends and near-term applications relevant for the telecommunications industry. It incorporates select elements from the five associated domain-focused workshops in the series.

Course Outline

The Future X Network Vision

  • Explain the value of time: of saving and generating time.
  • Review the digital pyramid of human needs.
  • Explore the evolution of productivity gains as a result of technology evolutions.
  • Introduce the eight value vectors of Future X networks and operations.

The Market Drivers

  • Highlight the evolution of customer demand. Elaborate on current end user desires - life style shift, enriched communication, video and gaming experience.
  • Elaborate on evolving Industry desires - automation, robotics, and Industry 4.0.
  • Discuss the emerging need to connect everything and the value of cognition and context.
  • Explore and emphasize the need for inherent security and privacy.

Services Evolution

  • Discuss the evolution of services and their impact on traffic growth and predictability.
  • Emphasize the significance of latency-critical services.
  • Explain how growing processing needs are driving new architectural requirements (the laws of physics).
  • Address hybrid cloud services needs.

The Technology Evolution

  • Explore the 100-year, 100x shift in network architecture.
  • Discuss the need for processing power at the edge, optimizing for cloud-edge network functions, and distributed data centres.
  • Emphasize the importance of security and privacy by design.

The Business Evolution

  • Introduce the six megatrends in the industry.
  • Discuss the business value of cloudification and its financial impact on the balance sheet.
  • Emphasize the importance of managing tangible and intangible assets on the balance sheet and how to conduct business beyond service provider’s network.
  • Explain how to enable the zero-marginal cost strategy with emphasis on the zero-touch operation model.
  • Explore the advancement of massive scale access, smart network fabric, and analytics with IOT services.

Zoom-in to Cloud / SDN / NFV

  • Discuss how to realize value using new value levers.
  • Examine the new business models; explore which may prove right.
  • Understand operations cost savings.

Zoom-in to 5G

  • Explore the new types of service offerings.
  • Discuss the key technology enablers.
  • Discuss how network slicing and end-to-end programmability is being brought to life.
  • Examine new spectrum strategies.
  • Understand deep fiber and the essential cloud-edge.

Zoom-in to Massive Scale Access

  • Discuss the concept of universal access.
  • Understand the vision of the long-wires short-wireless principle.
  • Explore how wireless and wireline technologies will evolve.

Zoom-in to Smart Network Fabric

  • Discuss the vision for an integrated network operating system.
  • Understand the advancement of NetUNIX.
  • Explore resiliency concepts and IP/optical integration.

Zoom-in to Digital Operations

  • Understand the concept of the 4Ps.
  • Discuss the importance of NOC to SOC transformation.
  • Understand the role of automation in operations, on the path to augmented intelligence and machine learning.

Zoom-in to Industry 4.0 and IoT

  • Examine the connection of everything.
  • Examine the automation of everything.
  • Explore strategies for creating value with platforms.

Note: the course outline is flexible, and can be adapted on special demand
Objectives:
Through the Future X Introduction workshop, you will:

  • Understand the Bell Labs Future X vision, its eight value vectors and its relevance to digital transformation
  • Gain insights into the assumptions, trends and service impacts of the predicted ‘100-year shift’ in network architecture
  • Understand the drivers and impacts of 5G evolution, hybrid cloud transformation, IoT proliferation, data analytics and digital operations
  • Recognize the steps to take today in preparation for these technology breakthroughs
  • Identify the opportunities and threats posed by the evolution of new Future X business and operating paradigms

This workshop is designed to be highly interactive with Bell Labs domain specialists leading focused discussions, sharing experiences and challenges, and examining strategies and best practices that you can start to implement today.
Duration: A two day highly interactive workshop delivered at a Bell Labs location in Europe, the Americas or Asia Pacific, or at a customer location upon request

Title: One-NDS
Description: One-NDS enables front end applications to share subscriber data by storing the data in a single centralized repository.

Title: One-NDS Delta
Description: This training provides the training path to  One-NDS release deltas.

Title: One-EIR
Description: One-EIR completes GSM and LTE network security after the commonly deployed Authentication Center (AUC), by adding a device identity validation based on mobile International Mobile Equipment Identity (IMEI)  numbers to the network.

Title: One-EIR Configuration & Administration
Description: Subscriber Data Management Configuration & Administration curriculum contains trainings paths for One-NDS, HLR and CMS8200

Title: One-MNP
Description: One-MNP provides Fixed number portability and basic ENUM support to offer a complete Number portability solution catering to all domains.

Title: One-AAA
Description: Provides authentication, authorization and accounting services for subscribers in a converged, multi-domain environment.

Title: Nokia HSS/HLR
Description: The Nokia HSS solution acts as home subscriber server with standard compliant HLR and HSS functionality, providing secure access to subscriber database functions for subscriber profiles and authentication data to support 2G/3G/4G/IMS network access and subscriber authentication, inter-domain roaming, subscriber services and administration for the network and service domains.

Title: Subscriber Data Management Delta
Description: This curriculum provides the delta learning solution for experience technicians and engineers release features updates for Subscriber Data Management.

Title: Subscriber Data Layer
Description: Subscriber Data Layer (SDL)  is our new product which will be commercial available starting in release 18. SDL is designed for the Cloud and 5G ready environment. SDL is not only a subscriber data repository but provides an open, cloud optimized data layer for all VNF data allowing for data sharing and analytics. SDL and One-NDS can coexist in the network therefor providing a stepwise approach for migrating VNFs.

Title: IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) -CFX-5000 17.5 System Administration Curriculum
Audience: This curriculum consists of 10 short web-based courses applicable to IMS (CFX-5000) release 17.5 regardless of which hardware or Cloud platform. This curriculum covers IMS fundamental concepts, the Nokia IMS solution components and CFX-5000 functions, operational and system administration tasks.
Description:
Curriculum Contents

CN37350-D-1000 Introduction to Nokia IMS Solution (22 mins.) – optional

• Describe the Nokia IMS solution architecture and components

CN37531-D-1751 Administration Interfaces for CFX-5000 (1 hr. 12 mins.)

• Describe the administration interfaces

• Perform configuration management using NetAct and OM Agent

• Perform fault management using NetAct and OM Agent

CN37532-D-1751 CFX-5000 Hardware Platforms (15 mins.)

• Describe the ATCA hardware

• Describe the HP hardware

• Describe the Nokia Airframe hardware used by Cloudband

CN3734-D-170 CFX-5000/CMS-8200 IMS 17.0 Functional Delta on Bare Metal to Cloud (2 hrs.) optional

• Describe the virtualized CFX-5000 (CSCF)

• Describe the virtualized CMS-8200 (HSS-FE)

• Describe the virtualized CMS-8200 (DRA)

• Describe the operational differences between IMS on ATCA, IMS on HP and IMS in the Cloud

CN37533-D-1751 CFX-5000 Registration (1 hr. 48 mins.)

• Describe subscriber registration from LTE access networks and from the Wi-Fi area

• Explain various types of authentication procedures

• Set parameters for registration-related scenarios via NetAct

• Set parameters for roaming policy control on P-CSCF, I-CSCF and HSS via NetAct

CN37534-D-1751 CFX-5000 Session Handling and Routing (1 hr. 12 mins.)

• Describe message flows for session handling and routing

• Set parameters for session handling in IMS

• Describe supplementary services via application servers

• Set emergency call parameters

• Describe resource management for application servers

• Perform node monitoring

CN37535-D-1751 CFX-5000 Interface to IP Connectivity Networks (Gm Interface) (42 mins.)

• Configure GM interface for IP connectivity

• Perform PCRF administration in IMS

• Perform SBC administration in IMS

CN37536-D-1751 CFX-5000 Session Handling for I-SBC (1 hr. 20 mins.)

• Configure registration and session handling parameters for roaming

• Configure optimal media routing parameters

• Configure optimized bearer path

• Configure message manipulation

CN37537-D-1751 CFX-5000 Session Handling for SRVCC and eSRVCC  (42 mins.)

• Describe registration handling and session anchoring for VCC

• Describe transcoding after eSRVCC

• Configure parameters for domain transfer from LTE to CS

CN37538-D-1751 CFX-5000 Charging (1hr. 20 mins.)

• Describe offline charging in IMS

• Configure offline charging parameters

• Describe online charging in IMS

• Configure online charging parameters

Audience

This training is designed for persons who need to operate and maintain the CFX-5000.
Objectives:
By the end of the curriculum, participants will be able to:

• Describe the fundamentals of IP Multimedia Subsystems (IMS)

• Describe the Nokia IMS solution

• Describe the IMS administration interfaces

• Describe the functional delta between IMS on bare metal and on Cloud

• Describe CFX-5000 registration

• Describe the CFX-5000 interface to IP connectivity networks (Gm interface)

• Describe CFX-5000 session handling and routing

• Describe CFX-5000 session handling and configuration for I-SBC

• Describe session handling for SRVCC and eSRVCC

• Describe charging and configuration of parameters
Prerequisites:
• Telecommunications and IP knowledge

• Knowledge of TCIP, SIP and other Internet Protocols

• Basic knowledge of IMS (IP Multimedia Subsystem Solution)

• Basic knowledge or experience with NetAct 16.x or higher management functions for CFX-5000
More information:
Introduction to the Nokia IMS Solution (22 mins.)

Administration Interfaces for CFX-5000 (1 hr. 12 mins.)

CFX-5000 Hardware Platforms (15 mins.)

IMS Functional Delta on Bare Metal to Cloud (2 hrs.)

CFX-5000 Registration (1 hr. 48 mins.)

CFX-5000 Session Handling and Routing (1hr. 12 mins.)

CFX-5000 IP Interface to Interconnectivity to IP Networks (Gm Interface) (42 mins.)

CFX-5000 Session Handling for I-SBC (1 hr. 20 mins.

CFX-5000 Session Handling for SRVCC and eSRVCC (42 mins.)

CFX-5000 Charging (1 hr. 20 mins.)

Title: IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) CFX-5000 and CMS-8200 17.0 Troubleshooting
Audience: This course describes how to troubleshoot CFX-5000 and CMS-8200 on bare metal (ATCA/HP) and Cloud (VMware and CloudBand) using diagnostic tools.
Description:
Course Content Topics

Introduction to the Nokia IMS solution

• Describe the 3GPP IMS network architecture

• Specify the Nokia products to realize the Nokia IMS solution

• Describe the ATCA and HP-based bare metal IMS architecture

• Describe the VMware and CloudBand virtualized IMS architecture

OAM Interfaces, Usage of cmcli and TSP WEB GUI

• Briefly describe the OAM Interfaces

• Use the Configuration Management Command line Interface tool (cmcli)

• Connect to TSP WEB GUI and use the appropriate management functions

• Perform fault management and internal trace

• Check counter values

• Check processes and subsystems

Diagnostic tools

• Specify diagnostic tools that can be used to troubleshoot IMS (e.g. RapidStat, RtpDumpLog, …)

• Practice the use of the existing diagnostic tools to collect diagnostic data

Basic System Check

• Perform basic system checks

• Practice the use of the correct tools (e.g. Alarm Checks, netstat, …) and procedures.

Symptom Collection

• Perform symptom collection by applying the learned procedures and diagnostic tools.

• Practice network packet capturing (e.g. by using snoop and tcpdump) and analysis with Wireshark tool.

• Describe how Load balancer logging is performed

• Describe IP plumbing

Case-Based Troubleshooting

• Recognize successful and unsuccessful IMS registration

• Recognize connection problems

• Recognize other problems, like missing domain, realm, PCRF problem, …

• Execute for the above-mentioned cases the troubleshooting procedures and find the root cause

• Apply the solutions for the above recognized root causes.

Reference Material

• IMS operations documentation

Audience

Personnel who maintain and troubleshoot IMS 17.0
Objectives: Upon completion of this course, the student will be able to troubleshoot CFX-5000 and CMS-8200 on bare metal (ATCA/HP) and Cloud (VMware and CloudBand)
Prerequisites:
• Linux knowledge

• Knowledge of the Nokia IMS Solution

• Good knowledge or extensive experience  with CFX-5000 administration and operation and CMS-8200 provisioning and administration
More information: CFX/CMS IMS 17.0 Troubleshooting (2 days)
